newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgian company considers voice access to Internet.
newsitem.headline: Belgian company considers voice access to Internet.

text.p: A Belgian company is considering developing speech recognition products for access to the Internet, according to an interview published on Wednesday.

Gaston Bastiaens, Chairman of Nasdaq-listed Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products, told Belgian daily De Financieel Economische Tijd the products could help those who did not speak English to use and explore the network, where 90 percent of information is in English.

Comparing the Internet to a large library where all the books lie scattered on the floor, he said that with the new products "that library will be within everybody's reach, irrespective of the language they speak."

Founder Jo Lernout said he and co-founder Pol Hauspie would also never give up their majority in the company, ruling out speculation of a potential takeover by Microsoft, which uses Lernout & Hauspie's text-to-speech technology as the linguistic standard in its software development.

Lernout & Hauspie, set up in 1987, currently employs some 500 people. Its technology allows computers to recognize speech automatically, transform computer text into speech, or convert speech into digital signals.
The technology is currently available in a number of languages including Dutch, French, German, Italian, and Korean. Other languages are under development.
